Package net.happybrackets.core.scheduling

Class HBScheduler

java.lang.Object
net.happybrackets.core.scheduling.HBScheduler
public class HBScheduler
extends java.lang.Object
Stores events with the time they need to be executed and executes them when they are due. These include Clock, Delay and DynamicControl
The global getGlobalScheduler() is the scheduler most scheduled events are triggered to. Moving the getGlobalScheduler() forward or backwards in time will cause the objects to have their events moved accordingly.
It is possible to run multiple HBScheduler if you want to synchronise to more than one epoch.
The time is stored in milliseconds a a Double, with the zero REFERENCE_TIME being 1 Dec 2018 on the System Clock.
The Scheduler can be synchronised to the System Clock through the function synchroniseClocks(). The offset between the scheduler and the System Clock can be obtained through getClockSkew() The scheduler can, however, be set to any time independent of the System Clock through calls to setScheduleTime(double) or adjustScheduleTime(double, long). The current scheduler time can be obtained through getSchedulerTime()

  • Method Details

    • setDeviceController

      public static void setDeviceController()
      Use a flag to set this as Controller so we can send messages from simulator as well as controller

    • enableProcessControlMessage

      public static boolean enableProcessControlMessage​(java.lang.String device_name, int message_id)
      See if we will process a control message based on device name and message_id If the message_id is mapped against the device_name, ignore message, otherwise store mapping and return true;
      Parameters:
      device_name - the device name
      message_id - the message_id
      Returns:
      true if we are going to process this message

    • getGlobalScheduler

      public static HBScheduler getGlobalScheduler()
      Get singleton instance of HBScheduler
      Returns:
      the single static instance with maximum priority

    • displayNotifyMessage

      public void displayNotifyMessage()
      Set flag to display notify messages to stdout for debugging and testing

    • getClockSkew

      public double getClockSkew()
      Get the amount of time difference between system clock and our scheduler
      Returns:
      the amount of time difference between two clocks

    • synchroniseClocks

      public double synchroniseClocks()
      Synchronise our timer with the system time on next tick
      Returns:
      the number of milliseconds we will be moving scheduler

    • synchroniseClocks

      public double synchroniseClocks​(long slew_time)
      Synchronise our timer with the system time
      Parameters:
      slew_time - the amount of milliseconds that we want to take to complete it
      Returns:
      the number of milliseconds we will be moving scheduler

    • getCalcTime

      public static double getCalcTime()
      Get the calculated time in ms from 1 Dec 2018 from System Clock
      Returns:
      number of milliseconds since 1 Dec 2018 GMT

    • endScheduler

      public void endScheduler()
      End our scheduler. Any items scheduled will be deleted

    • reset

      public void reset()
      Erase all Scheduled objects from clock

    • addScheduledObject

      public ScheduledObject addScheduledObject​(double scheduled_time, java.lang.Object param, ScheduledEventListener listener)
      Add an object that needs to be notified when its scheduled time has occurred If the scheduled time on this item is less than the current next scheduled item We will notify the scheduleObject so it waits the appropriate time
      Parameters:
      scheduled_time - the time the item needs to be scheduled for
      param - the parameter to be passed back to the listener
      listener - the listener to be called when the scheduled event is supposed to occur
      Returns:
      the scheduled object that has been added

    • getSchedulerTime

      public double getSchedulerTime()
      Get the Scheduler time in milliseconds. This function is particularly useful for scheduling event to occur in the future by adding the number of milliseconds in the future. An example of its usage is in FloatControl.setValue(double, double)
      Returns:
      the elapsed time in milliseconds

    • setScheduleTime

      public void setScheduleTime​(double new_time)
      Set the scheduler time to this time
      Parameters:
      new_time - the new time

    • adjustScheduleTime

      public void adjustScheduleTime​(double amount, long duration)
      Adjust the scheduler time. For example, to advance the scheduler 200 ms over a five second period, we would use the following code 
           HBScheduler scheduler = HBScheduler.getGlobalScheduler();
     scheduler.adjustScheduleTime(200, 5000);
      Likewise, a negative value will retard the scheduler time
      Parameters:
      amount - the amount of milliseconds we need to adjust our time by. A positive amount will advance the scheduler
      duration - the number of milliseconds over which we want this change to occur so we don't just get a jump

    • buildNetworkSendMessage

      public static de.sciss.net.OSCMessage buildNetworkSendMessage​(java.lang.String OSC_MessageName, ClockAdjustment adjustment)
      Build OSC Message that specifies a Network update
      Parameters:
      OSC_MessageName - The OSC Message
      adjustment - the ClockAdjustment we are making
      Returns:
      OSC Message directed to controls with same name, scope, but on different devices

    • ProcessSchedulerMessage

      public static boolean ProcessSchedulerMessage​(de.sciss.net.OSCMessage msg)
      Process our Scheduler messages
      Parameters:
      msg - the OSC message we are processing
      Returns:
      true if we process this message
